snippet: Though their numbers in Afghanistan remain low, Islamic State fighters have begun making inroads in Taliban territory.
abstract: Islamic State militants are seizing territory in Taliban-controlled areas of Afghanistan and in one district have replaced it as dominant insurgent power; ISIS only controls several remote villages, but Taliban, as it moves against Western-backed government, is forced to deal with insurgent threat of its own.

byline.contributor: Taimoor Shah contributed reporting from Kandahar, Afghanistan, and Khalid Alokozay from Bati Kot District, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: Though their numbers in Afghanistan remain low, Islamic State fighters have begun making inroads in Taliban territory.

headline.main: In ISIS, the Taliban Face an Insurgent Threat of Their Own
headline.print_headline: Inroads by ISIS Present Taliban With Their Own Insurgent Threat

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
